thread.title: Week 14 NBA power rankings: Heat stay hot, Raptors continue to struggle
thread.title_full: Week 14 NBA power rankings: Heat stay hot, Raptors continue to struggle

author: USA TODAY Sports
title: Week 14 NBA power rankings: Heat stay hot, Raptors continue to struggle
text:
Week 14 NBA power rankings: Heat and Mavs rising, Raptors plummeting The 14th of our weekly NBA power rankings (from Jan. 29 through Feb. 5) Post to Facebook Week 14 NBA power rankings: Heat and Mavs rising, Raptors plummeting The 14th of our weekly NBA power rankings (from Jan. 29 through Feb. 5)  //usat.ly/2jXEBp7   Join the Nation's Conversation   Week 14 NBA power rankings: Heat and Mavs rising, Raptors plummeting AJ Neuharth-Keusch , USA TODAY Sports 7:03 a.m. ET Feb. 7, 2017 CLOSE x Share USA TODAY Sports' Sam Amick breaks down the recent surge by the Sacramento Kings and how they could be contenders for the final playoff spot in the West. USA TODAY Sports Miami Heat guard Dion Waiters (11) reacts after being fouled during the second half against the Milwaukee Bucks at American Airlines Arena. (Photo: Steve Mitchell, USA TODAY Sports) CONNECT COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
USA TODAY Sports' NBA power rankings for Week 14 (Sunday, Jan. 29 through Sunday, Feb. 5) of the 2016-17 season. 
TEAM (RECORD) MOVEMENT 
1. Golden State Warriors (43-8) - 
Other than Saturday night's three-point overtime loss to the Kings, the Warriors have been hot, winning eight of their last 10 while posting an NBA-best 115.5 offensive rating. Back-to-back MVP Stephen Curry has followed suit, averaging 30 points (on 52.2% shooting), six three-pointers (on 51.4% shooting), 7.8 assists and 4.6 rebounds. 
2. San Antonio Spurs (39-11) - 
The Spurs boast the NBA's top defensive rating (101.3 points allowed per 100 possessions) and the league's second-best net rating (plus-9.5). This week, they recovered from losses to New Orleans and Dallas with wins over Oklahoma City, Philadelphia and Denver by a combined 54 points. 
3. Houston Rockets (37-17) - 
The Rockets, who have gone 5-5 over their past 10 games but still sit in third place in the Western Conference, have a favorable February ahead of them. Of their seven games, six are against sub-.500 teams and five are at home. PointAfter | Graphiq 
4. Cleveland Cavaliers (34-15) - 
After a 7-8 January and with trade rumors galore, the Cavs started off February on the right foot with wins over the Timberwolves and Knicks, but will have their work cut out for them with road games against Washington, Indiana and Oklahoma City on tap. 
5. Boston Celtics (33-18) +3 
Riding a seven-game winning streak ‚Äî headlined by wins over the Rockets, Raptors and Clippers ‚Äî the Celtics are just two games behind the first-place Cavaliers. What's more, starting shooting guard Avery Bradley (achilles) is expected to return this week. 
6. Utah Jazz (32-19) - 
Despite the fact that All-Star caliber forward Derrick Favors, who has dealt with a nagging knee injury all season, is averaging just 9.1 points and 5.9 rebounds in 22.9 minutes, the Jazz aren't only on pace for their first playoff appearance since 2012. They're on pace for homecourt advantage come playoff time, too. 
7. Washington Wizards (30-20) +3 
Led by All-Star point guard John Wall, a healthy Bradley Beal and a much-improved Otto Porter and Markieff Morris, the Wizards are the hottest team in the Eastern Conference. The Wizards, who are in the midst of a seven-game winning streak and 17-game home winning streak, have gone 24-9 since Dec. 1 ‚Äî the third best record in the NBA during that span. 
8. Los Angeles Clippers (31-20) -1 
Since Christmas, the Clippers have a 9-11 record, the NBA's 24th-ranked defense (110.6 points allowed per 100 possessions) and have a minus-2.5 net rating, which ranks 21st. They lost their ninth straight game to the Warriors on Thursday, furthering the distance between themselves and the Western Conference elite. 
"They performed at a much higher level than us, it wasn't even close," Clippers coach Doc Rivers told reporters after the loss. "They're a better team until we prove differently." 
9. Memphis Grizzlies (31-22) +2 
The Grizzlies won three of their four games this week (at Phoenix, Denver and Minnesota) by a combined 47 points. Their lone loss came to Oklahoma City on Friday as Russell Westbrook (38 points, 13 rebounds, 12 assists) recorded his 25th triple-double of the season. 
10. Toronto Raptors (31-21) -5 
Trouble in Toronto? The Raptors have lost seven of their last 10, including games against Orlando (twice), Phoenix and Charlotte and All-Star guard DeMar DeRozan has missed seven of Toronto's last eight games with an ankle injury. They're now in fourth place in the East, 4 1/2 games behind the Cavaliers. 
11. Atlanta Hawks (30-21) +1 
The Hawks put together a late-game comeback to beat the Rockets, 113-108, on Thursday night despite 41 points, eight rebounds and eight assists from MVP frontrunner James Harden. Hawks center Dwight Howard, who spent the past three seasons with the Rockets, led the way with 24 points and 23 rebounds. . @DwightHoward was a beast last night üí™ pic.twitter.com/EqHUU062mW ‚Äî Atlanta Hawks (@ATLHawks) February 4, 2017 
12. Oklahoma City Thunder (30-22) -3 
Warriors forward Kevin Durant, who spent his first nine NBA seasons with the Thunder franchise, returns home on Saturday for the first time since his offseason departure to The Bay. The game ‚Äî at 8:30 p.m. ET on ABC ‚Äî will be Durant's third time playing his former team this season. In the first two meetings? He scored 39 and 40 points, respectively, and led the Warriors to two wins ‚Äî 122-96 and 121-100. 
13. Indiana Pacers (28-22) - 
The Pacers, who are in the midst of a six-game winning streak, have a tough stretch before the All-Star break, with games against Oklahoma City, Cleveland (twice), Washington (twice) and San Antonio. 
‚ÄúRight now, we‚Äôre starting to learn, we‚Äôre starting to figure each other out, we‚Äôre starting to gain some identity and we‚Äôre starting to get some chemistry," All-Star forward Paul George said recently . "That‚Äôs the difference.‚Äù 
14. Chicago Bulls (25-26) +1 
The Bulls won two of their three games this week, taking down Philadelphia 121-108 on Sunday, Jan. 29 and Oklahoma City 128-100 on Wednesday. Their lone loss came on Friday in overtime to James Harden (42 points, 12 rebounds, nine assists) and the Rockets. 
15. Miami Heat (21-30) +11 
The Heat were 11-30 on on Jan. 14, in 14th place in the East and bound for the lottery. After Saturday night's 125-102 win over the 76ers, they're 21-30, just two games out of eighth place and looking like an entirely different group. 
"We're not thinking about the win streak," Heat center Hassan Whiteside told reporters after the win. "We're a whole different team than we were a month ago. Guys are healthy. Guys are playing together. We're a whole different team." Whiteside - 30 & 20 in 26:47!Only player in @NBAHistory to accomplish that faster? Bill Laimbeer (1985). 35pts & 21rebs in 21 minutes. pic.twitter.com/OWfnrGPE1Q ‚Äî Miami HEAT (@MiamiHEAT) February 5, 2017 
16. Detroit Pistons (23-28) +3 
The Pistons' mediocre 2016-17 continued this week, with losses to Eastern Conference foe Boston and Indiana and wins over New Orleans (118-98) and Minnesota (116-108). 
17. Charlotte Hornets (23-28) -3 
The Hornets, in the midst of a seven-game losing streak, rank 20th in the NBA in fourth quarter points allowed (25.9). They also have the NBA's worst defensive rating (124.6 points allowed per 100 possessions) in clutch situations (final five minutes when the score is within five points). 
"I think we're sixth in fourth-quarter offense in the league, but we're 19th or 20th in fourth-quarter defense," Hornets coach Steve Clifford told reporters after Saturday's loss to the Jazz. "Our first few years we were top five. ... Our fourth-quarter defense has been our biggest problem." 
18. Denver Nuggets (22-28) -2 
The highlight of the Nuggets' week came on Friday, when budding star Nikola Jokic returned from a three-game absence (hip) and posted the first triple-double (20 points, 13 rebounds, 11 assists) of his career en route to a 121-117 win. Nikola Jokic notches his first career triple-double for the @Nuggets with 20 points, 13 rebounds & 11 assists! #MileHighBasketball pic.twitter.com/LhVwzUKycm ‚Äî NBA (@NBA) February 4, 2017 
19. Milwaukee Bucks (22-28) -1 
The Bucks snapped their five-game losing streak on Saturday with a 137-112 rout of the Suns, but after losing eight of their past 10 games, they sit a 1/2 game out of the Eastern Conference playoff standings ‚Äî a far cry from what they're capable of. 
20. Portland Trail Blazers (22-30) -3 
The Trail Blazers, a game behind the Nuggets for eighth place in the West, play five of their seven remaining February games on the road, where they have an 8-19 record this season. 
21. Dallas Mavericks (20-30) +4 
The Mavs' week was highlighted by the emergence of Yogi Ferrell , who scored a career-high 32 points in Friday night's win over the Trail Blazers. Riding a four-game winning streak, which is tops in the Western Conference, the Mavs are creeping up on the playoff picture, just two games behind the eighth-place Nuggets. What a night for the rook... as @nbadleague alum @YogiFerrell11 puts up 32 points... including 9 threes to tie the most by a rookie! #MFFL pic.twitter.com/wOfsbbnx7U ‚Äî NBA (@NBA) February 4, 2017 
22. New York Knicks (22-30) - 
The Knicks, who sit 1 1/2 games out of eighth place in the East and whose lone win of the week came on Wednesday against the Nets, have a tough February ahead, with games against the Clippers, Spurs, Thunder, Cavaliers and Raptors on the schedule. 
23. Sacramento Kings (20-31) - 
The Kings snapped their three-game losing streak with a shocking 109-106 win over a sloppy Warriors team on Saturday, led by All-Star center DeMarcus Cousins, who finished with 32 points, 12 rebounds and nine assists. It was his 21st time this season scoring 30 or more points. 
24. Minnesota Timberwolves (19-32) -3 
Forgot the fact that the T'Wolves lost three of their four games this week. Their biggest lost came on Friday night against the Pistons, when starting shooting guard Zach LaVine suffered a torn ACL. The 21-year-old was having a career-year, averaging 18.9 points (on 45.9% shooting) and 3.4 rebounds. 
25. New Orleans Pelicans (19-32) -5 
The Pelicans have lost their last four games (Washington twice, Toronto and Detroit), but it looks like All-Star forward Anthony Davis may be finally getting some frontcourt help. According to USA TODAY Sports' Sam Amick , the Pels are in serious trade talks with the 76ers to acquire second-year big man Jahlil Okafor. 
26. Orlando Magic (20-33) +1 
The Magic, who lost three of their five games this week (Minnesota, Indiana, Atlanta), rank 27th in the NBA with a minus-6.2 net rating on the season and have the NBA's 22nd ranked defense despite the offseason hiring of defensive-minded head coach Frank Vogel. When asked about his team's defensive effort after the 113-86 loss to Atlanta, Vogel described it as "terrible." 
"It's disappointing. It's just disappointing," he told reporters . There's no other word for it." 
27. Philadelphia 76ers (18-32) -3 
Plagued by injuries to Joel Embiid (knee contusion), Robert Covington (hand contusion) and Jahlil Okafor (knee soreness), the 76ers have come back down to earth a bit, losing three straight and five of their last six. Still, they're just two games away from their highest win total since the 2012-13 season. 
28. Phoenix Suns (16-35) - 
The bright side of the Suns' three-loss week? Rookie forward Marquese Chriss put together the best stretch of games of his young career, recording a career-high 20 points in Monday's loss to the Grizzlies and 27 points in Saturday's loss to Milwaukee. 
29. Los Angeles Lakers (17-36) - 
The biggest news in Laker Land this week came on Thursday, when the team announced that Hall of Famer Magic Johnson will return to the organization as an ownership adviser. According to a news release sent out by the team, Johnson's duties will include, but won't be limited to, "advising ownership on all business and basketball matters, collaborating with coaches, evaluating and mentoring players, assessing future franchise needs and helping ownership to determine the best path for growth and success." 
30. Brooklyn Nets (9-42) - 
The Nets, who have one win in 2017 and a .176 winning percentage on the season, are on pace for their second worst season in franchise history, trailing only the 2009-10 New Jersey Nets squad that went 12-70. 
"Teams play with a lot of confidence against us," guard Joe Harris told reporters after Friday's loss to the Pacers. "Guys look at our record and where we are in the league and they play with a lot of confidence. They're very aggressive and it's making it very difficult for us to close out games." 
List of voters: USA TODAY Sports' Jeff Zillgitt , Sam Amick , Kevin Spain , AJ Neuharth-Keusch and Michael Singer ; The Arizona Republic's Doug Haller ; The (Memphis) Commercial Appeal's Ronald Tillery ; Detroit Free Press' Vince Ellis ; Indianapolis Star's Nate Taylor ; The (Bergen) Record's Steve Popper ; HoopsHype.com's Jorge Sierra and Raul Barrigon ; USA TODAY Sports Weekly's Howard Megdal .
